source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_022_chunk2
evidence_span: Cladding hydrogen content was measured by vacuum fusion mass spectrometry. Representative cladding specimens were analyzed from a number of test rods and the results are summarized in Table 1 [4,8]. Hydrogen contents varied from 40 to 390 weight ppm hydrogen in cladding specimens analyzed from the film boiling zones of test rods that did not fail.

evidence_span: The concentration of absorbed hydrogen varied among the rods that failed, ranging from 40 to 1020 weight ppm hydrogen in regions near fracture locations.

evidence_span: The presence of a continuous β phase matrix (containing transformed α′ platelets) in the two-phase region results in somewhat higher values of microhardness (>290 DPH) than were found in two-phase material when the β-phase matrix was discontinuous (<235 DPH) within a continuous primary α phase matrix.

evidence_span: Quenching fracture in anomalously embrittled cladding specimens exhibited failure both normal (Fig. 5) and obliquely to the maximum tensile directions under multiaxial stressing conditions in-pile.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_022_chunk4
evidence_span: An example of oblique failure, shown in Fig. 6, exhibits through-wall cracking at an angle roughly 34 deg to the radial direction normal to the wall. Other fracture angles typically observed were ~57 and 64 deg.
